Organization Description 4: Data Scientist  UOB (Optimum Payroll) Singapore  December 2016 to Mar 2017   APPLE PAY MODEL:  Apple Pay is a software/hardware capability on Apple iPhones that enables credit card payments at point of purchase directly from the phone. This year Bank of America has committed to double BAC Apple Pay adoption from approx. 800,000to 1.6 million users. Because it is such a anew technology there is no literature or experience on how to drive usage increase. The Model development team’s conjecture is that the fastest path to increase usage is to target customer that are similar to the ones currently using Apple Phones.  Model Development Purpose and Intended Use:  This model has been developed to support marketing to increase Apple pay adoption and usage. This Model will guide who is targeted in adoption marketing campaigns for Apple Pay.  This Model is based upon classification and regression tree(CART) model that identifies customers that have a high propensity to use Apple Pay. The population being studies consist of those customers hwo has phone capability to use Apple Pay application. The depended variable is an indicator that the customer has actually used Apple Pay or not. The model identifies the customer that look likes those who are currently using Apple Pay. Customers so identifies will be priories for initial market campaign. My primary project at Taiger was a signature extraction engine, where I applied manual feature extraction with OpenCV, as well as deep learning methods on TensorFlow to perform document analysis and pattern recognition tasks. Organization Description 1: I work as a core data science team member for developing Anti-Money Laundering System (AMLS) product especially the Name Screening (NS) Module of AMLS. I am a member of the Global Client Success Team which handles successful end-to-end delivery of product to clients globally. As part of the job, I use tools like Python, Hive, Spark, Scikit-Learn, Pandas, etc to carry out required ETL, Predictive Modelling and Reporting tasks.
Organization Title 2: Data Scientist and Artificial Intelligence Engineer
Organization Description 2: At LYTIQ, I had laid down the foundation pipeline for addressing a challenging medical image analysis research problem. The problem was to develop a convolutional neural network based deep learning solution to perform semantic segmentation for determining count of nuclei undergoing mitosis in the digital pathology data comprising Hematoxylin and Eosin stained cancerous tissue slides. The pipeline was developed using PyTorch, OpenCV 3 and Scientific Python stack. The experiments were run on local system as well as on Google Cloud Compute Engine. Along with laying down the foundation, I had mentored a team of 5+ interns for further enhancing the foundation research work.  One of my achievements at LYTIQ was to help the company in becoming a Gold Partner of Microsoft in Data Analytics Competency. see less
Organization Description 3: I worked as a TA under Dr Amit Dhar for the course of IDAA-432C i.e. Design and Analysis of Algorithms for fourth semester students. The number of students enrolled were over 200. I was given the task of evaluating assignments of students which included their lab codes, reports and class presentations. I was also given the task of examining answer sheets of students after their mid-semester and end-semester examinations. see less
Organization Description 4: I worked as a TA under Prof G.C. Nandi for the course of IITP-132C i.e. Introduction to Programming for first semester students. The number of students enrolled were over 290. I have taken up their class lectures and labs on topics in Python as relevant to the course.
Organization Description 5: Having been selected in prestigious Summer@EPFL 2017 program among thousands of students worldwide, I worked on a research project titled - "Supervised Q-walk for Learning Vector Representation of Nodes in Networks" in the realm of network analysis which involved developing a method for learning vector representation of nodes in a network. The method was inspired by a recently proposed node2vec framework. The latter framework is unsupervised, whereas my approach was a supervised adaptation leveraging label information for improving upon the quality of the learned representation of nodes. The project was developed using Python 3.5, NetworkX, Numpy, Matplotlib, Scikit-learn, Gensim on Intel Xeon powered Ubuntu 16.04.  This project was done individually as part of Summer@EPFL 2017 programme. "...Throughout his internship, Naimish put an extraordinary amount of passion and hard work into his project. He ran extensive experiments and regularly provided detailed updates to me. Finally, he compiled his findings in a thorough report. In the process, Naimish has broadened his machine learning expertise significantly through self-directed study.  I am confident Naimish will fare very well in the remainder of his Master’s degree and wish him the very best for his future career. " - Prof Robert West, Assistant Professor, Data Science Lab, School of Computer and Communication Sciences, EPFL see less
Organization Description 6: I worked on a project titled - "Facial Key Points Detection using Deep Convolutional Neural Network - NaimishNet". With my convolutional neural network based deep learning model, I could secure 18th rank on Kaggle leaderboard in Facial Key Points Detection Challenge. The project deployed scientific python with deep learning libraries like keras with theano backend.  "...To best of my knowledge and judgement, Mr. Agarwal's work not only constitutes not only a mere implementation but original research advancing the state of the art. I'd wholeheartedly like to thank Mr. Agarwal for his dedication, skill and hard work. Given the results of his work, I have offered Mr. Agarwal a full semester internship in my lab." - Jun. Prof Dr Artus Krohn-Grimberghe, Assistant Professor, AIS/BI, University of Paderborn  In 2020, I came to know that my work on NaimishNet is featured in Udacity's Computer Vision Nanodegree programme. My employer Tookitaki appreciated my research contribution in computer vision. see less

Organization Description 3: Rapyuta Robotics is developing cloud platform for robots such as Drones for easier autonomous deployments. My roles here were: 1. Cloud based RGBD-SLAM: Adapted and extended two different state­-of-­the-­art algorithms. Each algorithm can be divided into two phases. First, a visual odometry method is used to compute relative, local transformations of the camera. Second, keyframes generated from the first phase are are sent through an optimisation process that refine the transformations. My work consisted of implementing the firstcomponent on a low­-cost ARM embedded platform and implementing the second component on a cluster of servers in the cloud. I worked on this project independently and solved many of the technical and theoretical challenges on my own.  2. Aerial vehicle obstacle avoidance. I was responsible for operating over 20 successful live demonstrations to potential clients, and in a team of 3 assisted in maintaining the functionality of the system for demonstration purposes. see less
Organization 4: Nara Institute of Science and Technology
Organization Description 4: There are several operations of mobile robots, such as security, cleaning etc., where they have to repeatedly move in the same area for long term(weeks or months). In such scenario, the robots can use global map, constructed once using SLAM, for navigation. However, there might be changes in the environment around the robot while it is operating. These changes might be due to people moving or objects such as furniture that is displaced. In these situation, it is crucial to update the map used by robot for navigation. The changes due to furniture items are termed as low-dynamic as they can be observed only in between multiple traversals. In this work, a novel inference method to detect positions of objects such as furniture etc. is proposed. The proposed method is tested on standard datasets(consists of weeks of observations) and as well as on simulation testbed.The results show robust detection of low-dynamic objects even in the presence of occlusion. The work is also published in international conference. see less
Organization Description 5: Robust mapping in indoor environments for navigation. Traditional localization and mapping techniques assumes static(non-changing) environment, but in real world operation the environment around robot is rarely static. Therefore, a robust mechanism to update the map, generated by robot, is required. In previous studies, occupancy grids are used to model these changes and maintain an updated map. In this study, a novel inference approach on occupancy grids is proposed to model different dynamic changes in map. The main aim of this study is to maintain updated map for robots working for long periods such as weeks. Implemented inference model for occupancy grids using Explicit-state Duration HMM and tested it on Long term dataset. We are able to track the areas effected by dynamic objects on a month long operation of robot. Even in cases of occlusion the actual dynamic regions are estimated robustly. see less

Title: Data Scientist @ AIDA Technologies Pte Ltd
Organization Description 2: • Took on two projects as part of the OTAAG: Operations, Technology and Advanced Analytics Group.  • Project I: Developing an End-to-End Task Automation Suite • Background: The project is a web-application to which users can upload various workflows (read Python, R, and various other scripts) and execute them automatically according to some fixed schedule. After a workflow is executed, an email is sent to the user which contains any output or errors encountered during the execution of workflows. Further, if any output files are generated along with the execution of the workflows, those too are sent in as attachments along with the email. • The web-application was developed using Django 2.0.6 with PostgreSQL as Database back-end. • Celery, a Python based scheduling library was used for task automation in real-time. • Redis was used for managing real-time job queues.  • Project II: Predicting Equipment Failures for Minimising Faulty Hard Drives • Background: Hard Disks are filled with Helium gas which is difficult to seal and contain. A Hard Disk is sealed with the help of screws which are inserted with the help of a "screw bit". Hundreds of thousands of screws are put in place every day and the screw bit eventually wears out with use. A worn-out screw bit improperly puts in the screws, thus improperly sealing the Hard Disks. An improperly sealed Hard Disk would fail the "Helium-Leak" Test. Thus, it is pertinent to predict the right time to replace the screw bit to prevent faulty Hard Disks as well to minimize the wastage of screw bits. • Analyzed the error logs from the manufacturing machine and found a relevant trend in the occurrence of a certain error code which strongly correlated with "bit wear". • Developed a trigger mechanism which analyses the occurrence of errors in real-time and raises an alarm when the bit wear occurs. Implemented Multi-Objective Optimization to balance between maximizing the detection of bit wear and minimizing false alarms. see less

Organization Description 1: I worked for the GM Lab, whose goal was to leverage machine learning to automate processes and understand client behavior better. - Maintained and improved the intelligence part of an effort to automatically price emails containing tables of EQD quotes. My module parsed the table and mapped each line into a price request. Each field was an automatically-taught model (RANSAC or lightgbm). The system was eventually able to deal with over 40,000 quotes per week. - Maintained and expanded the scope of a module that parsed and tagged chats containing a quote for a FX option to build a pricing request. Model language : BERT. Part of the system was in production and dealing with hundreds of quotes per week, the rest was still being integrated into the bank's systems. see less

Organization Description 3: I built a dataset scraping data from an online encyclopedia encompassing biographies and location data. I used Python on this project.
Organization Title 4: Intern in the Economic Survey Department
Organization Description 4: The French National Institute of Statistics developed a microsimulation model called Destinie, which aims at estimating the expenses facing the French pension system in the next thirty years. My work was to re-estimate the parameters governing the decision to retire. To this end, I worked on the "Echantillon interrégime des cotisants" and "Echantillon interrégime des retraités", two datasets containing comprehensive information on the careers and pension system contributions of hundreds of thousands of individuals. I worked on the datasets with SAS and a dash of SQL (through proc sql). Estimations were computed using R. see less
Organization Description 5: I taught classes on decision under uncertainty and game theory to first year students at Ecole Normale Supérieure de Cachan (which corresponds to their third year of undergraduate studies).
Organization Description 6: MAPP Economics is a consultancy advising firms on competition issues using economic tools. I was part of a team working on several projects. One of our client was a firm involved in an abuse of dominant position case. Another was alledgedly colluding with its competitors. In both cases, we used a mix of economic theory and econometrical techniques to build a counterfactual framework, determine whether damage might have been caused to the economy and assess its level. I cleaned datasets and computed estimations using Stata. see less
Organization Description 7: The Fourth Chamber of the French Court of Audit is in charge of reviewing institutions depending on the Ministries of Interior, Foreign Affairs, Defense, Justice, as well as the Prime Ministry. I worked alongside magistrates to analyse the accounts and efficiency of two state-owned companies. I also participated in the audit of a Prime Minister service.
Education Description 1: The ENSAE (Paris Graduate School of Economics, Statistics and Finance) is a French "Grande Ecole". I was directly admitted in second year as part of a scheme where students from other "Grandes Ecoles" can apply for a joint diploma at ENSAE.I attended advanced courses in economics as well as econometrics and statistics. I was also given the opportunity to complete an applied statistics project, working with professional statisticians.
Education 2: The London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE)
Education Description 2: The MSc Economics programme is composed of three core courses (Microeconomics, Macroeconomics, Econometrics), as well as an option course. I chose to follow the empirics-oriented Economic History class. Using the recent literature, we gathered precious insights on economic mechanisms and built a toolbox for dealing with endogeneity, drawing causal links, as well as creating original datasets (through scraping for instance). I completed an extended essay on the impact of French labour court composition on unemployment at a local scope. Since endogeneity is plausible in this case, I instrumented using data on strikes in the XIXth century. I compiled a wide number of heterogeneous datasets using Python, and performed Lasso estimations in a 2SLS framework with R.
Education Description 3: The Ecole Normale Superieure de Cachan is a French "Grande Ecole". I was admitted following competitive exams prepared during a two-year intensive program in math, economics and economic history.  During the first year, I was awarded "Licence" degrees in both economics and management.Throughout the second year, I attended both classes at ENS Cachan and the first year of the Empirical and Theoritical Economics master's programme (in partnership with Paris I Panthéon-Sorbonne and the Paris School of Economics). I spent my last year abroad, at the London School of Economics.

Organization Title 5: Postdoctoral Research Fellow at the Citi-Lab (Inria, INSA de Lyon, Université de Lyon)
Organization Description 5: I worked with Dr. Samir M. Perlaza (Inria) and Prof. Jean-Marie Gorce (INSA de Lyon) on the timely topic of simultaneous energy and data transmission in centralised and decentralised multi-user networks.  Missions: - I defined and conducted research projects, solved problems and derived outstanding contributions using tools from information theory, control theory and game theory - I wrote deliverables in form of international journal and conference papers - I gave tutorials and oral presentations in international conferences and workshops - I reviewed papers for well-known journals and international conferences - I served as a steering committee in workshops on communications under energy constraints Summary of contributions: I worked on simultaneous energy and information transmission in centralised and decentralised multi-user networks. I derived the theoretical limits on the information-energy trade-off in the Gaussian multiple access channel with and without feedback. This trade-off takes different facets depending on whether or not the network is centralised. I also addressed the fundamental limits of decentralised information transmission in the K-user G-MAC. Parts of these works were done jointly with Dr. Samir M. Perlaza (Inria), Dr. Ioannis Krikidis (University of Cyprus), and Prof. H. Vincent Poor (Princeton University). The derived results were published in several international conference and journal papers and were presented in three tutorials. see less

Organization Title 7: Visiting Researcher at the Electrical Engineering Department at Princeton University

Organization Description 2: • Training/probationary attachment • Use SQL to extract data and load to R and Python for data exploratory analysis, data scrubbing, feature engineering, and splitting data set to training and test data for supervised learning machine learning models. After which, the models will be trained, optimized, evaluated and re-optimized for improved performance and more accurate predictions  • A client from the healthcare industry wanted to predict the ratings of several drugs using information such as ingredients, dosage, side effects etc. First, Dominic divides the data into training and test set. Then, he normalizes the data using min-max normalization, which transforms the data into a common range, thus removing the scaling effect from all the variables and retains the original distribution of the variables. The scaled data is used to fit the neural network, which will predict the ratings. Dominic then validates the model by comparing the predicted ratings to actual ratings using root mean squared error (sum of differences between observations of both ratings). K-fold cross validation was also used to validate the model, so that every data point gets a chance to be in test set and training set.  • Dominic was able to conduct a statistical analysis to find out the trend for future revenue for a client in the transportation industry. At first Dominic uses ACF/PACF plots to determine that the data was non-stationary (mean and variance is dependent on time as plots did not show a quick drop-off in correlation after a small amount of lag between points.), so Dominic stationarize the time series through differencing by 1 degree. Given that the ACF shows no pattern of a smooth decay and decays to insignificance after lag 1, an MA(1) model was built to fit the data. Time series shows a gradual upward trend which is contrary to the volatile cyclicality of the unmodified time series see less

Usually, I develop our credit model from feature engineering to model training. Sometimes, I develop some other useful models, such as geohash and chatbot. Moreover, I am uninterruptedly monitoring, training and evaluating our credit model. I have explored and solved many special cases which influenced the stability of our model, such as some unstable features, special events and issues in our market.  In additon, I am developing a geohash project to present the street info from GPS point. This optimized our APP address selection UI, more customers authorized GPS to us. Organization Description 2: STW funded project ' Up-to-date maps and 3D city models using most recent point cloud and images for water management applications. The objective of this project is to identify the changes between the 2D maps and the 3D point cloud (captured after several months from the time of 2D map to be updated). Subsequently, updating the 2D maps and existing 3D city models with the identified changes in order to provide accurate and reliable data for building an up-to-date water runoff model. .. Keywords: 3D point cloud segmentation & classification, Deep learning (CNN, LSTM & Graph Convolution Neural Network), Change detection. see less
Organization 3: Faculty of Geo-Information Science and Earth Observation (ITC) of the University of Twente
Organization Description 3: My PhD research is part of the RECONASS (EU-FP7) project which is a collaborative work of ten research organizations from seven European countries. The objective of the project is to develop state-of-the-art tools for assessing the damages in buildings after a disaster event such as earthquake using various technologies such as wireless sensor network and remote sensing. As part of my PhD research, remote sensing based building damage assessment subsystem has been developed using 3D point clouds and very high resolution oblique images from manned aircraft and UAV platforms. This includes design and development of several methods for accomplishing the following major tasks: 1) Automatic delineation of individual buildings 2) 3D modelling of buildings using 3D point cloud 3) Image and 3D point cloud segmentation & classification 4) Automatic identification of various kinds of damage evidences required for damage assessment such as spalling, inclined elements, openings in building due to damage. . 5) Debris/rubble piles mapping and quantification in m3. 6) Synergistic use of remote sensing-based assessments with wireless senor-based assessments from other partners in RECONASS for improved assessment.  The methods developed through this research were integrated to build an automated damage assessment system which was thoroughly demonstrated using the data obtained through EU-FP7 project RECONASS (www.reconass.eu, a pilot project in the field of near real-time damage assessment). This demonstration yielded promising results, thereby highlighting the potentials of the developed system to scale well to applications in the real-world setting with minimal enhancements. see less

We give different prior probabilities to two types of binary labels in the Markov Random Field (MRF) model that label the coefficients as being significant or not. Title: Senior Data Scientist (Analytics) at Grab
Organization Description 2: “Grab is more than just the leading ride-hailing and mobile payments app in Southeast Asia. We use data and technology to improve everything from transportation to payments and logistics across a region of more than 620 million people. Working with governments, drivers, passengers, and charities, we aim to unlock the true potential of the region by solving problems that hinder progress.  Grab began as a taxi-hailing app in 2012, but has extended its product platform to include private car services (GrabCar & GrabShare), motorcycle taxis (GrabBike), social carpooling (GrabHitch) and last mile delivery (GrabExpress). Education FOS 1: Designing Multi-agent Framework for Unmanned Aerial/Ground Vehicles
Education Description 1: This thesis focuses on developing a multi-agent framework that allows seamless usage of unmanned aerial or ground vehicle for the same mission.  Multi-agent architectures for autonomous mobile robots are generally mission and platform oriented. Irrespective of the differences in aerial and ground robots, the algorithms for collision avoidance, path planning and path-tracking can be generalized.  SOIFRA, developed in this thesis, is an interoperable multi-agent framework focusing on generalizing platform-independent algorithms for unmanned aerial and ground vehicles. Algorithms for collision avoidance, path-generation and path-following and human collision avoidance are incorporated into SOIFRA. Collision avoidance is performed utilizing computer vision-based algorithms. VDPGT, developed in this thesis, is a platform independent real-time path-generation and path-following algorithm.  A human visual cortex-based system is developed to add human collision avoidance behaviour into SOIFRA.

Title: Data Scientist | Physicist | NTU
Organization Description 2: My research broadly focuses on understanding amorphous materials and polymeric systems.  Systems of macroscopic particles interacting via purely repulsive potentials undergo a jamming transition as their density increases, giving rise to mechanical rigidity to the system. The mechanical and transport properties of jammed materials originate from an underlying percolating network of contact forces between the particles. Our research concerns about the spatial correlation of the force network, the range of the correlations between the inter-particle forces.  Another strand of my research is focused on developing a new theoretical and computational framework to characterize the statistical features of suspensions of soft colloidal particles. These systems widely occur in biological and natural systems, and their understanding is important in technological applications such as cosmetics, three dimensional printing, drug delivery etc. The frameworks developed so far takes into account only effective two-body interactions, neglecting many-body interactions as they are too difficult to deal, both theoretically and numerically. Our research is to develop an original and flexible approach to describe the highly dense suspensions. Our formalism is a voronoi based, and it naturally takes many-body interactions into account.  • Optimization Techniques • Machine Learning : Regression Methods, Principal Component Analysis, Clustering • C/C++ and MPI based code development : Molecular Dynamics • Python for data analysis : cluster size and density distribution, correlation dynamics • Python, Gnuplot and Ovito for visualization • Voro++ (A C++ based library) for voronoi tesselation • Percolation Theory • Mentoring two undergraduate students on machine-learning based projects • Best presentation award in an International conference see less
Organization Description 3: Delivered a data science project with Electrical Power Research Institute (USA), a nonprofit organization conducting public interest energy and environmental research. This project was conducted in an agile framework, in an international team of four data scientists.  • Duties included data wrangling, exploratory analysis and predictive modelling • Quantified the aging behavior of cables, helping estimate cable's remaining useful lifetime • Identified the most relevant tests to assess the condition of cables, leading to significant reduction in cost and time for cable assessment • Identified patterns to be used for feature reduction in future research see less
Organization Description 4: In my post-doctorate work at Brandeis, I investigated active matter system. An active matter is a system where the constituents particles can harness their biochemical energy to produce mechanical motion. A central property of such systems is correlated behavior, as can be seen in birds flying together. The underlying fundamental physics behind such process in not understood and is a very active field of research. My research focused on developing a simple agent-based model to capture the correlated motion features . In our model, we observed the formation of transient defects, and emergence of novel patterns.  • Agent based simulations • C++ and Python for code development and data analysis • Ovito and Visual Molecular dynamics for visualization • Organized the seminar series for the soft condensed matter group. see less
Education Description 1: In my PhD, I investigated  the large time behavior of dissipative systems. The dissipative nature increases the complexity of the system  making these system not amenable to the tools and techniques of traditional statistical methods. We resolved the long-standing question regarding the large time behavior of energy loss, concluding that the theories proposed were not appropriate, and thus opening a new direction for developing a new theoretical description. We also developed a new computational model describing wave propagation in realistic dissipative systems, one of the first model to capture features as observed in experiment. We also improved the basic understanding of dissipative systems by incorporating realistic features such as rotation and friction.• Molecular dynamics simulations• Monte-Carlo simulations• Parallel Programming • Regression, Clustering• C/C++ for code development• Mentored PhD student

Title: Data Scientist at The Boston Consulting Group (BCG)
Organization Description 5: Health care service providers, and especially hospitals, still struggle to improve their patient flows and service levels with increasingly strained budgets. Hospital departments typically operate as individual units, therefore integration of improvement efforts are usually isolated and limited to optimization strategies for a single process step such as one clinic session, or one operating block, or one episode of a patient’s care path. In my thesis, I aim to overcome isolated improvement and optimization approaches, and to allow a scope wide enough to include complexity due to interaction of different patient groups’ care paths and different key hospital resources. By including a high degree of real-life complexities in our models, one is able to investigate interactions with higher accuracy, and detect different kinds of contingencies. The downside of complex models and solutions tend to be rather specific. However, generalizability is highly important throughout the research projects, and for all developed approaches and models. Keywords: Patient scheduling, Optimization, Dynamic rostering, Patient care path, Discrete-event simulation. see less
Organization Title 6: Research Assistant at the Centre for Systems Informatics Engineering
Organization Description 6: The objective of the centre is to create a high quality and influential research hub for developing research methodologies and implementation tools in system informatics, knowledge mining, quality engineering, and prognostics and system health management to serve the industries and societies in Hong Kong, Greater China, and the Asia Pacific region.  CSIE's mission is to: (i) encourage international research collaboration in theory and applications in informatics, knowledge mining, prognostication and quality engineering in the Asia Pacific region; (ii) bring together statisticians, mathematicians, engineers, computer scientists, and physical scientists to work on a variety of interdisciplinary research topics. (iii) provide an excellent collaborative research platform and environment for interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary researchers from all over the world.  Our quantitative research approaches include, but are not limited to, data mining, diagnostics and prognostics, system health management, stochastic simulation, computer models, and sensor-based inspection technologies. see less

Organization Description 5: Lego A/S, doing business as The Lego Group (stylized as The LEGO Group), is a Danish family-owned company based in Billund, Denmark. It is best known for the manufacture of Lego-brand toys, consisting mostly of interlocking plastic bricks. The Lego Group has also built several amusement parks around the world, each known as Legoland, and operates several retail stores. The company was founded on 10 August 1932 by Ole Kirk Christiansen.T he word "lego" is derived from the Danish words "leg godt", meaning "play well". The word "lego" also means "I put together" in Latin, and "I connect" or "I tie" in Italian. In the first half of 2015, The Lego Group became the world's largest toy company by revenue, with sales amounting to US$2.1 billion, surpassing Mattel, which had US$1.9 billion in sales. August 11th, 2017, Lego announced that Niels B. Christiansen will become the new CEO, effective October 1st of that year. Title: Senior Data Scientist at Panasonic
Organization Description 1: Summary: Predictive modeling, deep learning, prescriptive machine learning, probabilistic forecasting. Ongoing projects: --Marketing analytics and product portfolio optimization with auxiliary data : Developing the engine for sales prediction with data on previous sales of different products, macro economy data and other data on related factors computed through cointegration techniques leveraging machine learning tools including ensemble learning, multilayer perceptron, Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) and Long Short Term Memory (LSTM). --Anomaly detection for predictive maintenance in large scale production: Developing a platform for anomaly detection to facilitate predictive maintenance leveraging Bayesian statistical methods, deep learning, supervised and unsupervised learning techniques. see less
Organization Description 2: Projects handled: -->Robust prescriptive analytics: Instead of just prediction the framework developed through this project goes one step ahead and makes prescription on what is to be done to minimize or maximize some objective function. By and large in real world problems the auxiliary variables (such as # of google searches, user review etc) that affect the final quantity of interest is ignored resulting in under-utilization of data. In this project the conditional probability distribution of the objective function is modeled as a function of decision variable and quantity of interest (say sales or revenue), conditioned on the auxiliary variable. Use cases: Applied different ML techniques such as local regression, random forest, correlation and regression trees and kNN under this framework. -->Data driven pricing with messy datasets: Developed an optimization engine for dynamic pricing which considers market competition by leveraging statistical machine learning and optimization, with unknown demand. Implemented a method for estimating the demand-price sensitivity form largely incomplete datasets (with ~70% missing/corrupted entries) to maximize the revenue. -->Real time predictive analytics for large sensor networks (IoT applications): Developed a method to select hundreds of sensors (out of thousands), for real time monitoring, maximizing the information content. Implemented algorithms for anomaly detection based on deep learning methods such as recurrent neural network (RNN) and long short term memory (LSTM). -->Risk modeling and management: Developed a model to quantify the catastrophic risk by using stochastic processes and designed appropriate business interruption insurance for supply chain disruption. -->Logistics (Deep learning for big data applications): Implemented a module based on deep learning models such as convolutional neural network (CNN) and RNN using TensorFlow and Keras, to predict the service time of a delivery assignment. see less
Education Description 1: Research focus: Machine learning, data analytics and optimization for cloud services.Project description:Developed optimization based models for revenue maximization and operational cost reduction for cloud service providers to increase the profitability. Applied various data analytics tools such as supervised and unsupervised learning for cloud service application.Tools used include: mathematical modeling of stochastic systems, convex optimization with appropriate relaxation, supervised and unsupervised learning, predictive modeling, and time series analysis.

Title: Data Science
Organization Description 4: At GIC, I was a member of the data science team which collaborated with investment teams to use data-driven techniques (NLP, Machine Learning and Spark) for trading signal research with the goal of generating alpha.  Project 1 (Based on http://hobergphillips.usc.edu/industryconcen.htm)  Using large-scale text mining of SEC filings and integrating momentum-based trading strategies, we built and evaluated a trading strategy. My contribution includes text mining pipeline implementation using Spark (Python, Java, Topic Modelling/LDA). Using topic modeling, we were able to identify latent relationships between companies (competitors/similar) using their product and business descriptions. This information is value added over the standard GICS classification of companies which is static and does not model the ever changing business world. I also performed deep dive analysis and prepared a case-study into the construction and behavior of text-mining & momentum-based trading signal.  Project 2: POC to evaluate Bloomberg’s New Analytics and Event Driven Feed product for alpha generation.  Data feed included 2-years of story and company level sentiment analytics scores along with raw news feed which can be used for alpha research.  Signal Research related work: Implemented the data cleaning and preparation pipeline for Bloomberg XML feed. Implemented data exploration/analysis & sentiment-based interday strategy. Implemented the backtesting framework on Spark and evaluated signal performance/returns over parameter space (region, holding period, sectors, etc.)  Sentiment Analysis Work: Feature Extraction for Sentiment Analysis - The goal for this task was to extract features for sentiment classification of financial documents. Expanded Loughran and McDonald Sentiment Wordlist using Wordnet Identified most predictive features for financial documents (Positive/Negative Sentiment Features) using text classification techniques. see less
Organization Title 5: Data Scientist,Machine Learning Incubation, SAP Innovation Center Network
Organization Description 5: Project CV-Job Matching:  As part of an initiative to build intelligent enterprise applications, SAP has initiated use cases to add intelligence via data and machine learning to existing products. As part of one such initiative, we are solving problems in the HR/Recruiting domain, such as recommending and ranking the best cvs received for a job, or recommending the best jobs for a candidate given his profile.  My role is dual. As a Data Scientist, I research, design and prototype suitable text mining and machine learning algorithms to solve a variety of problems that we face. As a Machine Learning Developer, I integrate the code and tests into the software repository. My goal is to build data products by bringing research and software development together. Organization Title 5: Detection and Estimation of Change Points in Dependence Structure
Organization Description 5: Modelling the dependence between random variables has become a valuable tool for analysis in economics and finance. In particular, copulas are useful statistical tools for modelling dependence between time series and our research is motivated by detecting structural changes in dependence between exchange rates. Our thesis proposes an alternate criterion for estimating the change point, which is motivated by the symmetry of the likelihood ratio test. Since these tests will not always have perfect detection, we also construct a bootstrap confidence interval for the true time of change. Through Monte Carlo simulations, the power of the tests, accuracy of the estimators and the performance of the bootstrap confidence intervals are studied. Our proposed techniques are evaluated then applied to European Euro and New Zealand Dollar foreign exchange data.  Looking at change points in dependence of time series such as foreign exchange. see less

Education Description 1: The exploitation of IMPATT devices has been restricted as they are commonly believed to suffer high noise levels. Since the devices operate at relatively high electric fields where the ratio of the electron and hole impact ionisation rates is close to unity, and therefore giving an inherently high noise level. My work has involved in the study of the intrinsic layer of a PIN diode (0.3µm bulk material at 300K), when the saturation current is dominated by quantum mechanical tunnelling of electrons or holes from the narrow band-gap material formed close to the p-type or n-type of the PIN diode respectively.The objectives of my PhD work is to model the process that the extremely low noise observed theoretically, using an ensemble Monte Carlo Simulation to study the noise generated in Silicon IMPATT’s operated at high frequencies.
